title: How to avoid writing 'chosen one' characters in any story - Quora

response.answer_text: How do you avoid writing them? Just…don’t write them. It’s not inevitable that there has to be one. Let your characters have the characteristic they have because they worked to acquire them, not because fate has somehow dealt them a hand that blah blah blah. Maybe the whole point is that that character can’t resolve the plot all on his or her ownio. Maybe the whole point is that the character has to learn to accept help. This, incidentally, is the plot of Howard Hawks’s Rio Bravo, in which John Wayne’s character behaves as though only he can fix the town until he realises that he can’t do it by himself.

Most of my protagonists don’t even want to be in the position they’re in. They’re essentially in the wrong place at the wrong time and get caught up in their adventure. That’s the opposite of “chosen” or “destined.” I think of them as reluctant. Also, make sure your protagonists are flawed. Nothing fatal, but they’re human (or in my case, alien) and they make mistakes. And your antagonists shouldn’t be 100% evil either. You should be able to argue from the antagonist’s perspective that what they’re doing has some redeeming value to someone (maybe only themselves).
